newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Union sees no movement in Portugal copper talks.
newsitem.headline: Union sees no movement in Portugal copper talks.

text.p: Talks between management and striking workers at Portugal's Neves Corvo copper mine ended with no breakthrough, a senior union official told Reuters on Tuesday.
Eduardo Lazaro, a representative of the mine workers union, said that management had repeated its demand for Sunday working.
"They just repeated their demands," he said.
A senior company official had already told Reuters that he doubted that the talks, brokered by the civil governor of nearby Beja, 250 km southeast of Lisbon, would achieve anything.

Somincor, the state-controlled company which has a 51 percent stake in the mine, is also insisting that unions lift the picketing which they say is preventing employees who want to work from getting to the mine.

The civil governor of Beja, Antonio Saleiro, told Reuters that he had warned unions that he would be forced to send in police if they continued to block the entrance with lines of pickets in defiance of the law.
Lazaro said that union representatives would now report back to striking workers on the outcome of the meeting with management.
"Personally, I think that the workers are going to continue with the strike," he said.
